title: Idea Navigation: Structured Browsing for Unstructured Text

coauthor: Robin Stewart, Linguistics and Philosophy, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT
author: Vladimir Zelevinsky, Endeca Technologies

So we carried out a formative evaluation to test whether users would understand this idea navigation interface.
After a brief introduction, choose to use it when given that option along with the search box and successfully complete tasks with its help.

We gave 11 users a range of search tasks which either depended on this noun verb relationship like we just saw, and also tasks which were abstract or subjective like finding quotations that you consider controversial.
The primary result of our study was that users usually started out by using keyword search, probably probably because they were most familiar with that, but we're not quite sure.
Then they progressed to idea navigation when the search results turned out to be inadequate.

So for example, in the looking for a controversial articles task alot of times they would start out by searching for controversy, but very few articles actually their controversial actually call themselves out as such.
So.
So they didn't really find anything interesting, so when it when that happened they turned to idea navigation, found terms like re segregate which they which then led them to controversial articles.

Overall, the users made 100 idea navigation refinements versus 61 searches, so they definitely were using the idea navigation and Moreover 79% of the completed tasks used idea navigation as the final step, right?
So they really really did like solve the task.
In many cases using using this instead of the keywords.
There's many ways that this could be extended.
Enhanced we could.
Include the ability to extract triples from more sentence types.
We use better techniques to group similar terms together, provide more query refinement features such as the ability to select multiple refinements in the same column.
For example, selecting Mrs Clinton and Hillary Clinton and it's in the same column.
We also expect that I do.
Navigation will be most useful in domains like Health Science, legal case studies and patents where searching for it's very important to search for concepts that depend on the nonverbal relationship.
And finally, we'd like to do a bigger comparative user study too.
To compare idea navigation with some of the other widgets that we have, like metadata, facets and tag clouds, which performs some of the similar.
Function.

So in summary, we've developed a method of extracting subject verb object triples that are suitable for summarizing and presenting directly to end users, and we've designed a faceted browsing interface for summarizing these triples and letting users easily navigate through them to help find what they want.
We'd like to thank our colleagues at Endeca and Mitc sale for their advice, feedback and support, and thank you for listening.
